awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 IEEE North American School for Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2023 IEEE North American School for Information Theory (NASIT 2023) will be held at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, USA, from June 19th to June 23rd, 2023. This grant provides support for the expenses of school participants from the United States such as graduate students and postdocs. Attendees will benefit by learning from senior colleagues, presenting their own research in poster sessions, and expanding their network with their community. Each award will cover registration, accommodation, and travel.

The IEEE North American School (NAS) for Information Theory is an annual event of the IEEE Information Theory Society; 2023 will be the 15th year the school will have held the event. The NAS provides a supportive environment where foundations for learning and long-term future scientific collaborations are established. NAS delivers interactive education for graduate students in mathematics, engineering, and computer sciences. It presents students the opportunity to meet and learn from senior researchers in academia and industry who present long-format tutorials. Student and post-doc participants present their research results in poster sessions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2023 IEEE North American School for Information Theory (NASIT ’23) was held at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, USA, from June 19th to June 23rd, 2023. The NSF travel grant provided significant support for the expenses of school participants such as graduate students and postdocs. These participants benefited from attending the school — learning from senior colleagues, presenting their own research in poster sessions, and expanding their network with their community. Each award covered the local expenses of the participant (registration & accommodation) and partial travel expenses. Using NSF's generous support, and by adding a (small) amount from other sponsors,  we were able to grant a total of 30 awards averaging $450 each. 

 

The IEEE North American School for Information Theory has been an annual event of the IEEE Information Theory Society since 2007. It has served as a prime education venue of the society. The school has been hosted by different institutions each year, with the double intent of (i) increasing the geographic diversity of the participants, and (ii) of involving faculty throughout North American in professional service, with the particular aim of giving junior faculty experience in organizing a conference. Student attendance at recent schools has varied from 60 to 100 student participants. Thus, by now many hundreds of students have enriched their education, learned about diverse research topics, and improved their connections within the community and network of collaborators through this event. We are happy to report that NASIT 2023 had more than 100 participants including students, postdocs, and a few faculty members who attended the school. Moreover, the School provided a supportive environment where foundations for learning and long-term future scientific collaborations are established. The School delivered interactive education for graduate students in the mathematical, engineering, and computer sciences. It provided the students the opportunity to meet with and learn from senior researchers from academia and industry who present long-format tutorials. Student and post-doc participants present their own research results in poster sessions. The IEEE Information Theory Society “Padovani Lecture'' was also delivered at NASIT 2023. 


As for the scientific topics covered in the event, we should first mention that Information Theory studies the transmission, processing, and use of information in many contexts; it draws from and contributes to a large number of disciplines in the engineering, computer, and mathematical sciences. At NASIT 2023, the types of research topics presented by students, and the tutorial areas discussed by lecturers, spanned foundational theory, algorithmic design, and implementation. Examples of topics discussed in school include:

o Information Theory and distributed/federated Learning (algorithms and fundamental limits for communication efficiency, privacy)

o Neural data compression
o Communication theory and networks
o Information theory and optimal transport
o Information Theory and Statistics
o Pattern recognition and learning
o Signal processing, sparsity, and compressed sensing, big data

NASIT 2023 was a week-long event that included a total of 11 tutorials by 11 distinguished speakers from the IEEE InformationTheory Society. This year we tried something new: We had long tutorials (3 hours) by senior members of the society as well as distinguished lectures by junior stars of the society. Our speakers were: Erdal Arikan (Bilkent U.), Salman Avestimehr (USC), Martina Cordone (U. Minnesota), Ziv Goldfeld (Cornell), Vahid Jamali (Samsung research), Hessam Mahdavifar (U. Michigan), Ayfer Ozgur (Stanford), Cynthia Rush (Columbia), Lucas Theis (Google), Yury Polianskiy (MIT), Christina Yu (Cornell). The event also contained multiple poster sessions in which students/postdocs presented their work. 

The organizers of the school were Profs Shirin Saeedi Bidokhti and Hamed Hassani from the University of Pennsylvania as the general chairs, as well as Prof Anand Sarwate From Rutgers as the financial chair, and Tara Javidi as the adviser. 

Here is the link to the webpage of the event that contains the details of the lectures and some pictures: 

https://nasit.seas.upenn.edu/home
